oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Two African American women and baby on porch of river dwelling
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two African American women are seated on the porch of an unsophisticated and weathered frame or log dwelling. A toddler plays at their feet. An empty ladder-back chair stands in the center door entrance, and a pail is stored in the corner. This cabin has two glass-pane windows, a single stone or brick chimney, and a wood shingle roof. Barrels sit in the yard on either side of the porch. A wide river appears in the background.
The origin of log cabins is uncertain. The humble cabin came to be associated with political campaigning. Seven U.S. presidents were born in log cabins.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Domestic life; Porches; Families; Log cabins; African Americans; Bodies of water
